ESSAY.P: was an intermediate between and . It is named after a shape-changing river god.
A large with unusual pelvic features.

This large animal had long vertebrae along its back, possibly forming a sail. The vertebral spines were 20-30 cm (8-12 inches) high along the neck and tail, possibly up to 50 cm (20 inches) along the back. It was once classified as a , since, like , it had long vertebral spines. But the rest of the animal is little like , and even the "fin" is different. It may be a late or an early .

ESSAY.P: One of the most famous and popular , is known primarily from the Morrison Formation. It probably hunted , , and perhaps gigantic like and . Its main rival was the slightly smaller .
There is debate over the taxonomy of these species. Some feel they should all be lumped into while others would split them into several genera (, , etc.)

This bulbous-snouted was previously referred to . It shows some -like features.

The name was once used to indicate remains of a theropod with high vertebral spines, similar to those of . In fact, the type material for this species is merely teeth, teeth which can not confidently be assigned to the same animal as the skeletal remains. The bones were reassigned to a new species of , another high-spined theropod. This species was called . But further study indicated that it could not confidently be said to belong to the genus . Hence, it was placed in a new genus and is now known as . is now a dubious species.

ESSAY.P: The origin of is associated with this creature, the "first bird" (nicknamed "Archie"). Although it resembled other small so much that one skeleton was for years mistakenly identified as , it bore feathers identical to those of . When it was first discovered in 1861, early evolutionists quickly recognized it as the "missing link" between birds and more primitive .

In many ways, was unlike modern birds. Like non- , it had a bony tail (short for a theropod, very long for a bird), teeth, and clawed fingers. It also had a hyperextendable "switchblade" claw on each foot, like its relatives the . But it was a bird and featured avian characteristics, like a reduced number of tail vertebrae and unserrated teeth.

Here is a table of known specimens (which are named after where they were first displayed):
Specimen Found Recognized Complete (feather) 1860 London 1861 Berlin 1876 X Maxberg 1956 Haarlem 1855 1970 Eichstätt 1951 1970 X Solnhofen 1987 X 1992 1993 X

REMAINS.content: forepart of skeleton with integument impressions

ESSAY.P: The specimen as originally published was touted as a - link. However, it appears instead to be a chimera, the tail and hindlimbs belonging to a deinonychosaur and the rest belonging to a bird. The name may be dropped for the formal publication of the animals. Until then, The Dinosauricon will use the name for the bird.
A poorly known dinosaur, has been classified as a , but it shows -like traits and may be some kind of .
Like birds and spinosaurs, it had unserrated teeth.

Some have suggested that the small, toothless(?) was feathered. It had little ridges running along its arms that may represent anchor points for feather shafts, although generally have bone "pimples" for anchor points instead of straight ridges.

This animal is difficult to classify. Its metatarsals were pinched, like those of , , and advanced . It may belong to any or none of these groups. It had some very bird-like traits, and its head was somewhat similar to . It has even been suggested that it may be a chimera made up of two different animals, but a recent find seems to dispel this idea.
may be related to and/or .

ESSAY.P: This tiny, long-armed, -like creature was originally thought to be a juvenile . It has the largest brain-to-body ratio of any non- dinosaur.
see also:
may represent a separate genus ().
Similar to .

possessed a number of characteristics that set it apart from other . The skull and (numerous) teeth were rather crocodile-like. Unlike most , the neck lacked a strong S-curve. There was a foot-long claw (for which the genus is named) on each hand. A piscivorous (fish-eating) lifestyle has been suggested for this 30-foot long predator, since fish teeth () and imprints of fish scales have been found in its belly.
So-named for its large, grotesque head.
Mentioned as an "omnivorouscarnivorous" .

The fourth non- discovered to have feathers or feather-like integument, from the same Early Cretaceous Chinese deposits as the other four (, , , and most recently ). ' integument seems somewhat similar to that of , but longer -- 5 cm on the average and up to 7 cm on the arms. The ends seem to have branching structures.

Apart from the integument, , a primitive , has features which show therizinosaurs to be , not or relatives as sometimes thought. Unlike most other theropods, therizinosaurs have four functional toes, like sauropodomorphs and some ornithischians. But ' feet, which have reduced inner toes, show that the therizinosaur condition evolved from a three-toed ancestor.
The head was relatively larger than that of other therizinosaurs, and it had some features similar to the related .
may represent the adult form of this animal.
May be an .
Had a hooked beak and sharp talons.

ESSAY.P: has been known for a while from scrappy remains, but only in recent years have new finds shown what a huge creature it was, rivalling and other as one of the largest land predators of all time.

A recently unearthed specimen was reported to have the largest head of any , although it seems that the skull was reconstructed too long. A realistic estimate for head length is 153 cm, which is less than ' 165 cm.
A misspelling of , in reference to indeterminate large material.

was an unusual . The name refers to the small horns it bore above its eyes. The arms were extremely small and underdeveloped, even more so than those of the . The forearms were so short that the hands appeared to sprout almost directly from the elbows. Remains are very complete, with skin impressions that show rows of large, non-bony, semiconical scales along the right side of the body.

was featured in the book The Lost World, where it was given amazing, chameleon-like powers of skin camouflage. Even if this is blatantly unscientific, it would've looked kind of cool on the big screen. (Unfortunately, wasn't put in the movie.)
A "" of some kind. Originally referred to .
May be the same as .

ESSAY.P: is one of the few non- for which feathery impressions are known. The only others (, , , and ) come from the same site and have also only recently been discovered. specimens were at first mistaken for specimens.

As the name implies, had a special assemblage of feathers on its tail, possibly for ornamental purposes. There are bands of dark and light on the tail feathers. These may be remnants of the animal's pigmentation, something that is hardly ever preserved.
had very short forelimbs and symmetrical feathers, meaning that it did not fly. It legs were long, perhaps for running and/or wading. A recent study has suggested that it was capable of perching.
The original cladistic analysis placed as a basal , but many now think it was related to .

ESSAY.P: Originally published as C. a'naensis, but the ICZN does not permit non-alphabetic characters in any taxon's name.
Although originally placed in its own family, was considered a despite not having front legs longer than hind legs, like . More recent analyses suggest that it is a very primitive .
May be a or a .
, a very common little hunter of the Late Triassic, came in two forms, "robust" and "gracile". These two forms, or "morphs", probably represent the two genders.

There was a recent disagreement over the proper name for . The type specimen (that is, the specimen used to define the genus) was rather fragmentary. Most of our knowledge of comes instead from dozens of very well-preserved specimens found at a site called Ghost Ranch. Some scientists recently argued that the Ghost Ranch might not necessarily be the same as the original specimen. They proposed a new name for the Ghost Ranch dinosaurs - . But by this time the association of the name with the Ghost Ranch material had become heavily entrenched in dinosaur terminology. The ICZN (International Committee on Zoological Nomenclature) voted to redefine the type specimen of as one of the Ghost Ranch specimens. So the name has been officially dropped.
The original type material, which may or may not belong to the same kind of animal as the neotype, has been given its own (dubious) genus: ("true ").
A skull from the Carnegie Museum of Natural History became the first dinosaur fossil to be taken into space on January 22, 1998 when the Endeavor Space Shuttle took off for Mir Space Station.
A misspelling of , in reference to some indeterminate small material.
May be the adult version of .
One of the very smallest non- .

There has been disagreement over the poorly preserved hand. One early restoration with a finned forelimb has been rejected. Usually it is depicted with two fingers, although it may well have had the usual theropod three, as its closest relative did.

The type specimen of probably represents the adult form, while the type specimen of is probably a juvenile. The adult was found with 10 eggs and a skeleton inside. At first it was thought that the skeleton was of a fetal , and that the animal gave live birth (ovoviviparity), but it turned out to be a (). This is direct evidence of ' predatory nature.

ESSAY.P: This is the oldest known (and the oldest known , for that matter). Also the only known from Antarctica, and the first from there to be described. It had an unusual crest projecting upwards from between its eyes.
Before formally published, this animal was referred to in literature as , named for its pompadour-like crest.
This genus was renamed because the name was thought to be preoccupied, but this was not the case. (The other animal, a lizard, was actually named .)
This animal filter-fed using the 260 tiny teeth in its jaws. had a porous crest on its head.
had a crest on the underside of its jaw.

ESSAY.P: sported a pair of thin crests running from above the nostrils to the back of the head. (At least, and did -- that part of the skull is unknown for .) These frills were probably ornamental in nature.

was featured in the blockbuster movie Jurassic Park. Considerable liberties were taken with the restoration. Real were much larger than their Jurassic Park counterparts. There is no evidence that they had neck frills or poison glands. In fact, was the largest predator in its environment and had no need to be poisonous. Furthermore, Jurassic Park's dilophosaurs had jaws simplified beyond recognition (the cool kink was utterly smoothed out).
had taller, more robust crests. It may not belong to this genus.
The name was first given to a species of .
Named for some scrappy remains, but the name was already given to another which turned out to be the same thing as . (And in fact even then the name had already been given to another creature!)

ESSAY.P: Once considered a (in fact, it was at one time used as a subgenus of ), this medium-sized predator is now recognized as a basal , albeit a very late-occurring one.
Some other large-ish, late-surviving, basal coelurosaurs, like seem to have some commonalities with . Together they may form a clade (Dryptosauridae).

It is unclear whether remains came from the 0 Formation or the Lance Formation. This uncertainty gives it its name. It may come from the Late Jurassic, like most other diplodocids, or it may be from the Late Cretaceous (Maastrichtian), and therefore the latest known.

, a recently discovered South American , outsized the largest known by a full five feet in length and two tons in weight. Except for a new, unnamed carcharodontosaurinae, it was the largest known carnivore ever to walk upon the surface of the Earth. Unlike , it may have hunted animals far, far larger than itself -- , largest land animals of all time.

A large enantiornithean.
was the first American non- to be described from a partial skeleton, and the first non-neornithean dinosaur skeleton to be put on exhibit. It is New Jersey's state fossil.

Discovery of back in 1858 showed that some dinosaurs were bipedal, correcting erroneous restorations of and as four-footed animals (although nowadays , , and all other are thought to be only semi-bipedal).
Despite being the genus which a large group of dinosaurs () is named after, is not well known. Missing the skull, the type specimen is indistinguishable from other . It may belong to a .

ESSAY.P: This was the first to be scientifically recognized. Along with and it was one of the first three creatures to be placed in .

was originally restored as a four-legged, rhinoceros-like beast. Later the "nasal horn" turned out to be a thumb spike. Its posture was changed to bipedal, since its hindlimbs were so much longer than its forelimbs. Nowadays it, like other large , is thought to have been facultatively bipedal, that is, primarily quadrupedal, but capable of moving on two legs as well.

as shown here may be a paraphyletic genus, with some species, such as , closer to . As with most old genera, there is some taxonomic sorting to be done. The type species () is based on very poor material.
and were rather gracile and long-spined, while and were more robust and short-spined.
This tiny creature may be related to . Both may have been very early .
May have had two horns on its head. Had a thick braincase.

had very odd hands. Most have a very short first digit, a long second digit, and a third digit somewhat shorter than the second. had a short first digit, a shorter second digit, and an even shorter third. All fingers were stubby, unlike those of most other , and the claws were small, unlike the large claws of its close relative .

Apart from the hands, it is much like other oviraptorids. It was suggested that it might have been the same as , but a different gender. However, the large difference in the hands between these two animals seems to go beyond sexual dimorphism.

SPECIES.name: challengeri
SPECIES.MEANING: Professor Challenger's (character in A. C. Doyle's The Lost World)

is known from the mid- of Australia, which was close to the South Pole at the time. It had very large eyes, which some have interpreted as an adaptation to the long period of winter darkness which occurs near the south pole.

ESSAY.P: Babies have been found of this . They hatched in great earthen nests, like those of crocodiles or mallee fowl, and were watched over by the parents. The nests, each containing 20-30 eggs, were grouped in colonies for better protection against predators.

Infant about three feet long have been found. The eggs were much smaller, on level with those of today's largest birds. The relatively tiny baby had a lot of growing to do before they could become 30- to 40-foot-long fully grown duck-bills.
had a very small, spiky crest in front of its eyes.
May be the same as , but material is too scant to be certain.

REMAINS.content: adult individual (nearly complete skull, most of tail), immature individual (incomplete skull, spine except for tail, ilium, ribs), etc.

ESSAY.P: . was originally thought to be a . Then it was synonymized with , an known from part of a jawbone. More recently, material has been judged too poor to make synonymy certain.
This animal had a small horn above its eyes. The skull was nearly 60cm long.

ESSAY.P: A nest of six eggs, 26 inches long and 22 inches in diameter, may belong to .
This was the first non- to be formally named and described ( had been discovered earlier, but wasn't published until later.) Along with and , it was one of the original animals placed in .
Early restorations showed it as quadrupedal(!) In fact, it and other had very short forelimbs, even for .
This genus has over the years been used as a grab-bag for all kinds of species, and even some non-theropods. There is much taxonomic sorting to be done on these.
Possibly a . If so, it would be the largest one, beating out . Its "sickle claw" was 14 inches long. This claw inspired its specific name, which is Mapuche for "foot lance".

It has been suggested that this may be the adult version of the . They are from the same time and place, and there is no overlapping material between them. More material must be found to verify or falsify this.
Based on remains originally assigned to .
Perhaps a .
Yet to be described. Based on two 2-inch-wide skull tops.
Tiny and bipedal.

bears the dubious honor of the with the longest generic name, with 23 letters and 9 syllables. For such a huge name, it was actually a pretty small dinosaur, one of the smallest of all non- dinosaurs.
When first found, was associated with the teeth of the larger . Hence it was reconstructed with an oversized head and informally dubbed ("fierce, big-toothed lizard").
Although sometimes classified as a , it is too primitive.

This animal has the shortest genus name of any non- .
Once considered an due to a supposed club at the end of its tail, but the club turned out to be an artifact of preservation. Instead, it is probably a very primitive .
May be the subadult of another genus or a valid genus with paedomorphic (juvenile-like) features.

Characteristics of the odd, singly-digited forelimbs seem to indicate proficiency at digging. These include a large olecranon and possibly the keel on the sternum. A mole-like lifestyle has been proposed, but this does not agree with the long, cursorial hindlimbs. Instead, it is possible that filled an ant-eating niche, similar to today's numbats and aardvarks.
Bore a small horn on its nose.
is known only from infant specimens, which were extremely small (nine inches long). The eggs were not much more than an inch long. may be the adult version.
Unlike other , may have replaced all of its teeth simultaneously, instead of one at a time.

ESSAY.P:
Could be the young of another genus.
Found in 1935 on the island of Sakhalin, which belonged to Japan at the time (hence the name).

was a smaller predator which sported a huge hyperextendable "switchblade" claw on each foot, much like those of and . The claws were different in structure, having a pit for the flexor muscle attachment instead of a knob as in the other two groups. The evolution of such superficially similar structures in three separate groups of small is a striking example of convergent evolution.
The only non- known to have a pygostyle (a fusion of vertebrae at the end of the tail).
Originally thought to be a , but could be a .

ESSAY.P: The first named genus with a click sound (the "q" represents a palatal click, made against the roof of the mouth).
The first digit had a very large claw.
The armor originally assigned to this species more likely belongs to a .
The type specimen for this name has been lost.
Tail clubs assigned to this genus are probably from large individuals.
Once classified as a , but now thought to be an advanced . Could be the body of .
Features of the hip and tail suggest that this may have been capable of rearing up into a tripod position, possibly for feeding.
The deposits this creature comes from are either Cenomanian or redeposited Albian.
Thirty-six species of have been named. Many are probably dubious or in need of reconsideration.
Once identified as a , this scrappy specimen may instead to belong to some kind of .
is not related to , but is instead a type of .
An erratum given for two separate animals which von Huene wished to transfer to
The archetypical "".
was originally placed in (and then ) because of -like toe claws, but the material is too indeterminate to assign confidently to any known genus.
Eggs formerly assigned to this genus have turned out to belong to .
Originally placed in , but may be an .
was remarkable in having a sail along its back, like that of the and the .

had a crest on its head, grasping hands, and an unusual penchant for being fossilized in interesting positions. The first one was found near what was thought to be the nest of a , presumably intent on snatching an egg. This gave it its name, which means "-loving egg raider".

In fact, analysis of the fetuses inside the eggs have since shown it to be the 's own nest. More recently, another oviraptorid (possibly ) has been found which died in a sandstorm while sitting on a nest of its own brood. These two discoveries show that probably cared for its offspring, as and do today.

was featured in the book Dinotopia, where it was renamed ("egg nurse"), since that was its function in the book's utopian society of prehistoric animals and humans. Strangely enough, the name given in the fictional book has turned out to fit the animal better than its actual name.
Originally identified as the remains of a .
This, the largest of , had a skull dome 10 inches thick.
had a large horny pad covering the top of its face, possibly supporting a truly gigantic horn, as well as several small, straight horns on the middle of its frill.
Originally classified as , but may be or .
This dubious genus, based on teeth, was one of the first American to be named. may belong to , and may belong to .

had the largest crest of any . It was a long, hollow tube which extended back from the skull, curving downwards. There may be a notch in its spine where the crest habitually rested.

SPECIES.MEANING: from the land of the Blackfeet (North American tribe)

ESSAY.P: Possible ancestor to .
The recently discovered ("before ") seems to have actually lived much later than , although it is more primitive. In fact, it may not even be an as first thought, but a more basal .
was about turkey-sized. Its forelimbs, proportionally shorter than those of flying animals, bore long, symmetrical feathers. Since all flying birds have symmetrical feathers, probably could not fly.

REMAINS.content: skeletal material from at least 2 individuals (possibly chimeric)

ESSAY.P: When this Triassic creature was first discovered, its describer declared it the earliest . This has been met with some skepticism, since the next bird (chronologically) does not occur until the Late Jurassic (). Some believe to be a chimera, made up of parts of different animals. Some bones may belong to a , others to some kind of .
There are two forms of , the "gracile" form, with low frill and flat snout, and the "robust" form with raised frill and a high bump on the nose. These probably represent the two genders.
One spectacular find from Mongolia shows a locked in combat with a . The two were buried by a sandstorm as they fought.
Eggs formerly assigned to this animal have turned out to belong to .
is the most primitive known (if not quite the earliest).
Proposed to give a type genus to the taxon Protrachodontidae, which had been named earlier.

was originally classified in , mainly due to its bipedal stance. One specimen was actually named ("before ", being a typical ornithopod). But was soon recognized as being closer to than ornithopods. In fact, it represents a transitional phase from early, ornithopod-like to the large, mostly quadrupedal .
This genus has more valid species than any other non- . Some think it should be split into more genera, although there have been no formal proposals.
One of the most popular , had no teeth, barely any tail, and a large crest on its head. The long crest of and stuck out behind, while 's crest was more vertical.

The name Miller, 1972 was proposed as a subgenus name for , but since this is the type species, the subgeneric name is, by default, . is the subgeneric name for ( was preoccupied). It is sometimes used as a separate genus name. has been proposed as the subgeneric name for the dubious species . Thus, these species are fully rendered as P. (P.) longiceps, P. (Geosternbergia) sternbergi, and P. (Occidentalia) occidentalis.

The genus was initially named as Ptero-dactyle by Cuvier in 1809 with no type species (which was permissible back then). The creature named by Soemmering in 1812 was recognized by Lydekker to be the same as Cuvier's Ptero-dactyle, so he transferred to the older genus Ptero-dactyle. Rafinesque later emended the spelling of Ptero-dactyle to in 1815.
This filter-feeding used its smaller upper teeth to comb out its lower teeth. The lower teeth fit outside the upper teeth.
had tiny fingers (except for the wing finger) and very large feet for a pterosaur.

SPECIES.name: olympius
SPECIES.MEANING: from the base of Mt. Olympe (Provence)

ESSAY.P: This new -like was perhaps the tallest. With its head raised, it stood 60 feet (nearly 20 m) tall.

was an early which marks a transitional stage between the small, bipedal and the larger, heavily armored . Some consider it a primitive ankylosaur, but it also bears a strong resemblance to primitive . It or something like it probably gave rise to both groups.
was most likely quadrupedal. There were interesting tricorns behind the ears. The back was studded with large, bony scutes.

ESSAY.P:
This extremely well-preserved shows traces of the intestines, windpipe, liver, and muscle fibers.
Previously known as the "Benevento theropod".
This miniscule animal may be part of the lineage that led to flying . It had long, thin legs which may have supported a flap of skin.

was a small, semi-bipedal, long-tailed similar to . In fact, it was often included with that genus in Fabrosauridae (=Lesothosauridae). But it seems instead to be an early form of . The back was covered in small, bony scutes.
One of the few from the Southern hemisphere.

The only known to have had a tail club.
This is the only for which the skull material is well-known. Its jaw shows definite characteristics.
This turkey-sized creature was quite similar to . Some bones previously assigned to have been reassigned to .
Chemical analysis of seems to reveal that it had feathers, or at least feather-like structures.
Proposed as an early , but that may not be the case.
Previously known as " B". May belong to .
Roughly -size. Was capable of perching.

REMAINS.content: nearly complete specimen with integument impressions

ESSAY.P: The fifth non- with remains of feathers or feather-like integument to be published. Of the five known so far (all from the same Chinese locality), is the one most closely related to . It has long been suspected that (a.k.a. "'raptors") were feathered -- this animal is the first proof of that.
has been diagnosed as a primitive, or basal, deinonychosaur. Its arms are proportionally very long -- 80% as long as the legs -- and its shoulder joint has features like those of flying birds.

The authors of this species have interpreted it as evidence for a "Ground Up" model of flight evolution (see ). However, it may instead lend credence to the idea that deinonychosaurs, and perhaps other coelurosaurs, are secondarily flightless (like birds), since it has more flight characteristics than more advanced deinonychosaurs.

REMAINS.content: 4 complete skeletons (one juvenile) with tissue impressions

ESSAY.P: was one of the most exciting paleontological discoveries of this century. Skin impressions seem to show a coat of small, feather-like structures (although some dispute this).

is important for at least two reasons. First of all, it is a major piece of evidence in favor of the argument that are descended from . Secondly, depending on its exact phylogenetic position, it shows that at least some non- were feathered. , , and are closer to birds than is, and, indeed, after was published, feathered animals from all three of these groups were found (, , and , respectively). It may also be that , , , , and even were closer to birds than was, making them probably feathered (or secondarily featherless) as well.
had three fingers, suggesting that its close relative (whose exact digit count has been debated) did too.

Like , one specimen of was found with a lizard in its gut. Another had remains of a small mammal. One specimen had two tiny eggs (about 37mm × 26mm) inside it, but died before it could lay them. It had a dual oviduct system.
had more tail vertebrae (64) than any .
About the size of a .

REMAINS.content: skull, ribs, scapula, hip bones, limb elements, tail & back vertebrae, gastroliths, etc.

ESSAY.P: Mistakenly assigned to , , and before official publication.

REMAINS.content: fragmentary dentary, vertebrae, hindlimb elements, teeth (destroyed in World War II); neck vertebra, fragmentary dentaries, dorsal neural arch

ESSAY.P: The gigantic has been estimated at up to fifty feet long. It was possibly the longest , but not the biggest, since it was more lightly built than the heavier and .

As remarkable as its length was, even more interesting was the huge sail along the back, formed by long vertebral spines, up to six feet in height at places. The exact nature of this bizarre sail is not known. It may have been used for heat dissipation, like the ears of modern-day elephants. Or perhaps it was a sexual signal. Similar structures were present in the and the , two living at the same time and area as . Some primitive amphibians and proto-mammals such as and also bore similar sails back in the Permian. Such parallelism across so many diverse groups is a strange phenomenon.
Once thought to be a , but may be a .
Once thought to be a synonym of .
May be a , the latest one known.

had an extremely small head for its size. It did not have enough brain matter to coordinate the movements of a 20- to 25-foot-long animal, and so it had a ganglion, or nerve center, in its hips to control the movement of the hindquarters. This so-called "second brain" (although it wasn't a real brain) was actually larger than the brain.
was the largest . Its largest plates were over two feet high and wide.

Recent finds show that the plates were in two alternating rows, not two paired rows. The tail spikes were held horizontally, not vertically. Small bony ossicles covered at least the the throat and hips.
may belong in a separate genus (), as may .
Similar to . The two may be very early . The braincase assigned to this species has tyrannosauroid features, although it does not necessarily belong to this genus.
May be a .
Originally thought to be a (hence the name).

GENUS.name: Stygimoloch
GENUS.MEANING: River Styx (Hell Creek Formation) Moloch (Ammonite/Phoenician god)

ESSAY.P: was unusual (and cool) in having bony spikes around its dome, somewhat similar to the .
Known from vertebrae and a hindlimb, has been assigned to the Hell Creek , although it might be the body of .
Formerly known as the "Jordan ". Could be the same thing as .
In addition to a large nasal horn, was equipped with horns lining the edge of its frill.

AUTHOR.name: Sereno, Beck, Dutheil, Gado, Larsson, Lyon, Marcot, Rauhut, Sadleir, Sidor, Varricchio, G. P. Wilson, J. A. Wilson

ESSAY.P: This had a two-foot-high sail over its hips. Some think it may be the same as .
One of the hugest land animals of all time. Stood 27 feet (8m) high at the shoulders and had at 40 foot (12m) long neck.

"Ultrasaurus macintoshi" was to be a name for some giant bones from the Morrison Formation, but before it was published the name was given to a smaller, dubious Korean sauropod (which was originally though to be larger because they misidentified a humerus as an ulna). The giant American sauropod's name was changed to . More recent analysis indicates that this creature is made up of bones from and a large , so the name is defunct.
had two small crests, similar to those of larger coelophysoids like .
Individuals thought to be juveniles have been reevaluated as adults of a distinct form to be given its own genus (provisionally called "Shake-N-Bake theropod").
The skeletons assigned to may not belong to the same species as the type material (teeth).

AUTHOR.name: Allian, Taquet, Battail, Dejax, Richir, Veran, Limon-Duparcmeur, Vacant, Mateus, Sayarath, Khenthavong, Phouyavong

ESSAY.P: May be the same as .
Skin impressions show that and an unnamed species had a stretch of skin supported by two crests on its head, one above its nostrils, the other behind its eyes. This may have been for sexual display.
Could be a primitive or a more primitive .

AUTHOR.name: Rich, Vickers-Rich, Gimenez, Cúneo, Puerta, Vacca

REMAINS.content: dorsal, sarcal & caudal vertebrae; rib fragments; girdle & limb (fore and hind) elements, associated skin impressions

ESSAY.P: The (incomplete) dorsal centra of this animal bear similarities to the Asian . The girdle and limb elements, on the other hand, resemble .
Very primitive for such a late-occurring . Its skull was more similar to and its kin.
Spherical eggs found in clutches of two to four have been tentatively assigned to this .
This primitive had an extremely long tail.
One specimen was found in association with several , suggesting that it may have been preyed upon by packs of these small .

REMAINS.content: teeth, vertebral centra, cranial fragment, partial scapluocoracoid, ends of ilia, limb elements, armor
over 100 elements (juvenile to adult), skull, partial skeletons

ESSAY.P: The most primitive well-known .
Originally classified as a small ("coelurosaur"), but may be .

REMAINS.content: partial forelimb, foot, vertebrae, hindlimb, claws, tooth

ESSAY.P: was named for remains from the southern Gobi Desert, which included huge claws measuring up to 28 inches (and that's without the horny sheath that covered them in life!) as well as seven-foot-long arms and some flattened ribs. They were originally thought to be remains of a giant -like creature (hence the specific name ).

More remains were found in Kazakhstan, Transbaykalia, and Inner Mongolia in the late 50's, including a partial forelimb, partial hindlimbs, and a tooth. The new discoveries showed that was not a turtle at all, but a , probably a new kind of . (The ribs of the first specimen may belong to a .)
was kept in its own group for a long time. Only recently have scientists discovered its close relation to the bizarre segnosaurs (now known as ).

One of the most striking characteristics of (apart from the myriad of striking characteristics it shares with other therizinosaurs) is the huge, blade-like claws on the hand. Other therizinosaurs had them, but none as insanely large as those of .

Many ideas have been postulated about these claws. It has been suggested that therizinosaurs used them to rip open giant termite nests, like anteaters and aardvarks. But the idea that an animal of ' size (over 30 feet long) could subsist on a diet of insects seems rather unlikely.

Instead, the claws may be analogous to those of the extinct giant ground sloths and chalicotheres (relatives of horses). Members of both of these groups were quite large in size and bore huge, blade-like claws on their hands. They were both herbivorous, as therizinosaurs probably were. It has been suggested that they used their claws when browsing to bring foliage closer to their mouths. They would also have come in handy as defensive weapons.
The giant is another mysterious theropod known mostly from gigantic arms. Strangely enough, it comes from the same time and place as .
Huge fossilized eggs found in Mongolia (13cm diameter, 45cm long) have been attributed to , or possibly .

PLACE.name: Alberta, Saskatchewan, Colorado, Montana, S. Dakota, Wyoming

REMAINS.content: 1 complete specimen, 8 partial skeletons, elements, teeth
complete skeleton with preserved ?heart, cartilaginous sternal ribs and plates attached to ribs, ?tendons attached to vertebrae

ESSAY.P: A new specimen of this genus may be the first dinosaur fossil with a preserved heart. If the structure is the heart, it confirms predictions, based on living dinosaurs () and the dinosaurs' closest living relatives () that dinosaurs had four-chambered hearts. The structure is similar to that of birds, suggesting high levels of activity. see

REMAINS.content: cranial fragments, vertebrae, limb elements, scutes

ESSAY.P: once had the largest known head of any land animal, with an eight-foot-long skull making up half its body length (excluding the tail). Recently, a skull was found with an even larger skull.
One of the first American to be named. Probably the same thing as another .

PLACE.name: Wyoming, Montana, S. Dakota, Colorado, Alberta, Saskatchewan

REMAINS.content: fragmentary skull including cheek and brow horns

ESSAY.P:
, the largest , was different from other in having a short, completely solid frill (in contrast to the large "windows" in those of other ceratopsines, especially ). This 30-foot-long herbivore has often been portrayed in combat with its largest predator, .
may be synonymous with .

The creature we know as was once called . The genus was first named (as Troödon) for some sharp teeth (one of the first American to be named). These were mistakenly identified as those of (among other things) a monitor lizard, a (), and a carnivorous ! They were later recognized as identical to those of the more complete specimens, so the younger name was dropped in favor of the older.
Eggs formerly assigned to have turned out to be . Some have been found in dirt nests.
may be a distinct species, or even genus ().

REMAINS.content: 2 skulls, elements from at least 4 individuals

ESSAY.P: This "unicorn " had a thin, hollow crest jutting forward. Some argued that the crest was an artifact of preservation (an altered snout bone), but another specimen was found with the same feature.
Had fifteen pairs of triangular plates down the back and two pairs of spikes on the tail. The best-known Asian .
Could be the only Asian , possibly a .

PLACE.name: Alberta, Saskatchewan, Colorado, Montana, New Mexico, N. Dakota, S. Dakota, Wyoming

REMAINS.content: skeleton lacking some neck vertebrae, forelimbs, most of tail
skeleton lacking tail tip, forelimb, foot

ESSAY.P: , possibly the most popular ever, was for a long time the largest known terrestrial predator. But new discoveries of have recently ousted the "king of the tyrant lizards" from its title. But there still remains the possibility that an even larger specimen may be found some day. And it was the largest known predator of its time, at the end of the Mesozoic Era.
The most complete skeleton, a female(?) (=) nicknamed "Sue", was recently sold for over $7 million by Sotheby's to corporate benefactors on behalf of the Chicago Field Museum.

Recently an enormous coprolite (fossilized piece of dung) from Saskatchewan was referred to . At 43cm in length and 2.4L in volume, this is the largest known coprolite from a carnivore. Tiny, well-crushed bone fragments indicate that the meal was a small subadult .
Eggs tentatively assigned to may belong to an Asian species of .

The various species included here in are sometimes placed in other genera. was originally , and sometimes is also included in that genus. Others put into its own genus, . Still others consider to be the subadult stage of .

and were thought by some to be pygmy , and were accorded their own genera ( and , respectively). But they seem instead to be juveniles. likely belongs to or , and likely belongs to . also likely belongs to , representing the subadult stage. It is sometimes placed in .
and , both dubious tooth taxa, probably belong to either or .
A misspelling of , in reference to indeterminate material.

REMAINS.content: skull (missing frill), partial pelvis, scapula, coracoid, fragments

ESSAY.P: The largest bipedal . Its jaw was very deep.
May belong to .

This animal was once thought to be a huge , and described as a species of Ultrasaurus, a huge North American sauropod. Unfortunately, Ultrasaurus macintoshi was not officially described at that time, so this Korean species accidentally became the type species of . The name of the North American species was changed to .
The "humerus" of this animal turned out to be a femur, so it was not as large as originally thought.

One of the closest non- to , this South American creature had a back-turned pubis, like and birds. It also had a shoulder joint that would allow flapping. itself was too big to fly, so it was probably secondarily flightless, like modern-day .
It was found in the same area as the larger . It has been suggested that they could be the same, being the juvenile or subadult form.
Originally claimed to be a giant, 35 feet (11m) in length.
May be the same as .

REMAINS.content: claws (hand & foot), tibia, lachrymal, premaxilla, tail vertebrae

ESSAY.P: The largest definite .

This animal's middle metatarsal was greatly enlargened, while the outer ones were reduced. This was probably an adaptation for running, opposite to that of many running (whose outer metatarsals became stronger, greatly reducing the inner one).
Sometimes considered a .
Possessed a "switchblade" foot claw, like those of and other basal .
The teeth (found in rock of volcanic origin) which this genus was named after actually came from a predator that may have eaten it. was similar to "", but probably the earliest .
Proposed as a , but, hey, it's just a tooth (an incomplete one at that). It could be anything.

REMAINS.content: partial skull roof, mandible, postcranial fragments

ESSAY.P: The last of the .
Based on material assigned to , to be re-described by Robert Bakker.
Probably either a basal or a primitive .
Possibly a relative of .

REMAINS.content: nearly complete skeleton (missing parts of forelimbs, skull, and tail)

ESSAY.P: Classified as a by its authors, but may not be. If it is an , it is the only one known to combine a long tail (at least 20 vertebrae; sans pygostyle; about half total length) and a lack of teeth (in the premaxilla, at least). The holotype was found in association with the .
seems to be a different type of than the type species, and will be given a new generic name.

REMAINS.content: skeleton without forelimbs, feet, or end of tail

GENUS.name: Yaverlandia
GENUS.MEANING: Yaverland Point (on the Isle of Wight) one

ESSAY.P: Usually considered a very primitive , although one recent study suggests that it is more advanced, despite its early occurrence.
Had broad spikes on its shoulders.
A -like maxilla assigned to this genus is now thought to actually be from a sauropod.

GENUS.name: Zephyrosaurus
GENUS.MEANING: Zephyr's (god of the west wind) lizard

ESSAY.P: The first known with brow horns, and the oldest named American ceratopsian.

REMAINS.content: partial vertebra, pelvic bones, shoulder bones, complete skull, etc.

ESSAY.P: If you were really bored and felt like going through the whole Genus List alphabetically one by one, you can stop now. (Or, if you're going backwards, quit now; you'll never make it).
